metadata.methodology: Similarity scores calculated using weighted algorithm: Muscle Activation (40%) + Joint Actions (30%) + Movement Pattern (20%) + Equipment (10%)
metadata.source: EMG studies, biomechanical analysis, NSCA, ACSM, peer-reviewed journals, physical therapy literature

substitutions.notes: EMG shows 13-25% higher pec activation with dumbbells; greater ROM (can descend below chest); independent arm movement corrects imbalances; 6RM load ~40kg dumbbells vs 88kg barbell
Optimal angle for upper pec activation (30% MVIC at 30°); maintains good overall pec activation; load typically 22% less than flat bench; same joint actions with angle modification
40% MVIC activation; closed kinetic chain increases core demand; ~75% muscle activation vs barbell; progressive difficulty: incline→standard→feet elevated→weighted
Limits ROM to prevent excessive shoulder extension; reduces shoulder stress by restricting descent; eliminates stretch reflex; maintains horizontal pressing pattern with safety mechanism
~70% chest activation vs bench press; lower chest activated 2x more than upper; requires forward lean 15-30° and wide grip; vertical angle reduces similarity but maintains pressing pattern

Vastus medialis 10-15% higher activation; 25% less erector spinae activation; more upright torso reduces spinal loading; prevents lumbar injuries during max loading; same joint actions with load position change
Nearly identical muscle activation; more upright positioning reduces shoulder mobility requirements; decreased forward lean; removes upper body restriction for those with shoulder issues
Anterior loading promotes upright torso naturally; lower absolute loading reduces spinal stress; excellent depth cue; same squat pattern with counterbalance effect and beginner accessibility
Similar quad activation but back squat shows higher hamstring activity; removes axial spinal loading entirely; guided path; body weight supported; loses stabilizer activation
Activates lower body similarly with ~50% load; unilateral addresses imbalances; greater gluteus maximus recruitment; hip-dominant; LOW-MEDIUM spinal stress
